body.name: Dictatorship: It's Easier Than You Think!
body.merchantInfo: Ships from and sold by glenthebookseller.
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews Review "...half-trenchant, half-goofball satire. This alarming guide to how democracies are lost is deceptively entertaining."―Publishers Weekly“Everyone who wants to grow up in a healthy democracy should know about Gaslit Nation.”― Historian Timothy Snyder, New York Times Bestselling Author of On Tyranny: Twenty Lessons from the Twentieth Century About the Author Sarah Kendzior is the author of the bestselling books The View From Flyover Country, Hiding in Plain Sight, and They Knew. She is the co-host of the acclaimed podcast Gaslit Nation with Andrea Chalupa and was named by Foreign Policy as one of the “100 people you should be following on Twitter to make sense of global events.” Kendzior has a PhD in anthropology from Washington University, where she researched authoritarian regimes of the former Soviet Union. She lives in St. Louis.Andrea Chalupa is the writer and producer of the award-winning journalistic thriller Mr. Jones, directed by Agnieszka Holland and starring James Norton, Peter Sarsgaard, and Vanessa Kirby, about Stalin’s genocide famine in Ukraine. She is the co-host of Gaslit Nation with Sarah Kendzior and helped launch #DigitalMaidan, a hashtag of Ukraine’s EuroMaidan Revolution and the 2017 March for Truth, demanding transparency in the Russia/Trump investigation. She graduated from UC Davis and regularly speaks about Ukraine and Russia to the press and schools. She lives in Brooklyn.Kasia Babis is a Polish cartoonist, illustrator and political activist with an online following of over 100,000 fans. Her viral comics succinctly skewer social issues ranging from racism to street harassment from a distinctly feminist perspective.
deliveryMessages: FREE delivery Thursday, February 22 on orders shipped by Amazon over $35
Or fastest delivery Tuesday, February 20. Order within 14 hrs 25 mins
body.description: Co-hosts of the popular podcast Gaslit Nation outline the authoritarian's playbook, illuminating five steps every dictator needs to take to successfully amass and maintain power.Do you crave the power to shape the world in your image?Can you tell lies without blinking an eye?Do you see enemies all around you?If you answered yes to all of the above, then this is the job for you! And if becoming a dictator sounds intriguing, well, you’ve just stumbled upon the playbook that will guide you step by step towards making your big lie a reality.Join Gaslit Nation co-hosts Sarah Kendzior and Andrea Chalupa, with artist Kasia Babis, on a journey from riches to even more riches. They’ll show you how to consolidate your authority, silence your critics, weaponize your citizens, and even prolong your inevitable downfall!Dictatorship! It’s easier than you think.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars this is important
reviews.reviewText: It's happening now and it won't end well, as all countries that elect rightwing dictators find out...too late

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2023
reviews.reviewText: So jam pact with clever illustrations and facts all too recognizable in our country , it was both funny and a dire warning to pay attention to what’s going on here politically.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Should be required reading
reviews.reviewText: This book should be required reading for every student prior to reaching voting age. The similarities among current and past dictators and would-be dictators is enlightening. Particularly helpful is the description of "useful idiot." The United States (including Congress) is full of them, so If you don't know one, you probably are one. Hopefully the authors and illustrator and their successors will regularly publish updated versions.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars I'd love it if I could read it
reviews.reviewText: This looked to be right up my alley: I'm a huge fan of one of the artists, and dictators are a subject of horrified fascination to me. I opened the book with eager anticipation, only to find that it's unreadable in digital format for me. From what I could discern from going through the art, I think I'd love this book, if only I could read it.Please consider not just vision-impaired readers like me; even average folks would struggle to make sense of 8-point font. Being able to zoom in is essential to reading comics digitally.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very good and sadly timely
reviews.reviewText: Digestible, depressing, and it should be required reading. It’s hard to not see how bad things are getting. Or that we’re close to a tipping point.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Brings all the authoritarian tricks and tactics into the light
reviews.reviewText: An easy to understand description of the tools dictators use to take over a country or culture.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent delivery of important information
reviews.reviewText: Love this presentation style and the information contained in this graphic novel.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars You've been warned!
reviews.reviewText: DICTATORSHIP; IT'S EASIER THAN YOU THINK, is an excellent book clearly explaining how dictators rise to power. It would be a great book to have on a required reading list to warn everyone how to recognize a rising dictator, strong-man, autocrat, while that person is not yet in power. The illustrations by Kasia Babis go along perfectly with the prose. Though DICTATORSHIP; IT'S EASIER THAN YOU THINK contains humor, it became a depressing read for me when I realized how easily we can be fooled into supporting a dictator as evidenced by how many authoritarian regimes there are today and have been in the past. I highly recommend this book.
